utterances: Yes.
Hi, there.
Hi, Neal.
The reason I'm calling is my son is going to be the best man at wedding, and it's just south of Cancun.
And he and a party of about 40 have chartered a plane, you know, rented a, you know, a hotel for the week, and they're all heading down there, leaving on Friday.
So, obviously, I was calling to see if there was any reason to be concerned about that.
The Health and Human Services Department is talking about nonessential travel to Mexico.
You ought to think twice about it.
But Dr. Neuzil, obviously, people have made a lot of expensive arrangements for weddings way in advance.
Is this essential?
Yeah, again, I don't think that that's for me to decide.
I would like to echo what you said.
There is a travel advisory.
People can keep up with these travel advisories and how they're changing on the Web site.
And I think that that is the best advice to follow.
And I would also alert people that the CDC Web site, www.cdc.gov is updated regularly, multiple times per day.
And again, this is a new situation.
It's changing fast.
I think we need to be prepared to keep up with changing recommendations.
I think John's question was if it was your son, would you tell him to go?
(Soundbite of laughter)
That'sâ€¦
And again, I think that - I really think that that's an individual decision to make, and we should follow the travel advisory.
Which says at the moment, don't go.
Exactly.
Okay.
There, John, you got an answer.
I got an answer.
All right, I don't know if he's going to like it, but we got an answer.
All right, here's an email question from Judith in Sacramento: How are different types of flu recognized in the laboratory?
Is it by spectroscopic patterns, or can different shapes be seen under a microscope?
Yes.
What they do, for example, at the CDC lab is actually, influenza virus has eight different parts, eight different genes, and they actually sequence the genes.
It's a molecular technique.
It's actually a little bit difficult to explain on the phone.
But they can get down to - it's not microscopic.
They can get down to a very fine level of detail in determining the virus, in determining how the virus is related to other viruses.
And if you were listening from the beginning of the program, determining actually how many different viruses combine to make a new virus.
You know, so a piece of this virus is from a pig virus, you know?
Another part of this virus is from a human virus.
So they can get down to, again, that actually map out the sequence of each individual gene.
So, there's not going to be a great scene.
Bill, come over, you got to look at this.
No, no, no.
No, no, no, okay.
Dr. Neuzil, again, we know it's a very busy day for you.
We appreciate your time.
Okay.
Thank you very much.

Kathleen Neuzil chairs the Influenza Working Group of the CDC Advisory Committee on Immunizations Practices and directs the influenza vaccine project of PATH, a nonprofit group focused on global health.
And she joined us today on the phone from her office in Seattle.
Joining us in shortly, after a short break, is Christopher Durang, and he's going to be with us to talk about his new comedy about torture.
I'm Neal Conan.
Stay with us.
It's the TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
The protests in Wisconsin illustrate the power of public sector labor unions.
While union membership is down across the country, government workers are a huge exception.
Many critics say public employee unions have used their clout to negotiate generous benefits, which they contend ought to be scaled back in the current fiscal crisis.
Union officials say they're being scapegoated for the economy's problems.
NPR's Jim Zarroli reports.
The public sector is one of the last bastions of strength for the labor movement - a little more than 9 percent of people who work for private employers belong to unions.
Among state, local and federal employees, the number is more than 36 percent.
James Sherk is an analyst at the Heritage Foundation.
Most union members now work in government.
A majority of all union members are government employees.
And that's true, even though many states, especially in the South, bar government workers from unionizing or restrict their bargaining power.
Nelson Lichtenstein, a professor of history at the University of California at Santa Barbara, says the strength of unions today is relative.
He says union membership has fallen overall because so many manufacturing jobs have gone overseas.
In the public sector, well, it's quite different.
You can't move the functions of the state of Wisconsin to China - they have to be there.
The Department of Motor Vehicles pretty much has to be in the locality where it is.
Because government unions have been able to maintain much of their power over the years, politicians have had to learn to coexist with them.
In recent years, strikes have been rare.
But the Heritage Foundation's James Sherk says in exchange governors and mayors have had to promise benefits that taxpayers couldn't afford.
For decades, elected officials have kicked the can down the road and promised you generous benefits to retirement and after they leave office.
Well, now we're at the end of the road and now, you know, the bill's coming due.
Many union officials take issue with that.

Art Pulaski of the California Labor Federation says government employees may get somewhat better benefits than those who work in the private sector but they earn a bit less, considering their education and skill levels and they have recently had to endure pay cuts and layoffs.
I think it's very important not to blame public workers for the crisis that our cities and states face right now.
All right?
I think that you really need to look at what was the cause of the economic crisis that perpetrated, if you will, the mess that we're in now.
And that really goes back to what happened on Wall Street.
Still, labor officials acknowledge that resentment is building against them and they're watching the current problems in Wisconsin with some trepidation.
Wisconsin was one of the first states to allow collective bargaining by government workers.
Nelson Lichtenstein of UC Santa Barbara says that if Wisconsin succeeds in curtailing their bargaining power, it will send a strong message across the country.

Unquestionably, if it happens in Wisconsin it'll be put on the agenda in Ohio, Pennsylvania, you know, every state where there is a collective bargain law for public employees and where there's a fiscal crisis.
If that happens, many union leaders fear public sector unions could see their power erode just as it has throughout the labor movement as a whole.
Jim Zarroli, NPR News.
Georgia's lieutenant governor is threatening to block a tax break for Delta Air Lines.
Delta announced over the weekend that it is ending a discount program for NRA members.
It joined a list of businesses that cut ties with the group after this month's school shooting in Parkland, Fla.
The Atlanta-based airline is the state's biggest private employer.
And joining us now to explain this standoff is Stephen Fowler from Georgia Public Broadcasting.
Hi, Stephen.
Hi, Ailsa.
So last week, the Georgia state House passed a sweeping tax bill that would overhaul the state's income taxes and make Georgians pay less income tax thanks to the recent federal tax bill.
OK.
One of the things that they stuck in there was a jet fuel tax break for Delta and other airlines in the state.
And what it would do is it would allow Delta to pay less for fuel taxes.
And Republican Governor Nathan Deal hoped that that would bring more flights into Atlanta and more businesses into Atlanta and overall be better for the state.
And that passed with little drama and little fanfare in the House until Delta decided to cut ties with the NRA.
Many Republican lawmakers objected to Delta's treatment of the NRA.

And Lieutenant Governor Casey Cagle, who's a Republican, said I will kill any tax legislation that benefits Delta unless the company changes its position and fully reinstates its relationship with the NRA.
Corporations cannot attack conservatives and expect us not to fight back.
I will kill any tax break.
I mean, this particular tax cut has come up before, right?
It's been used to apply pressure on Delta Air Lines in other instances.
So Delta actually lost that tax break in 2015 after it came out against a bill that some people said would discriminate against same-sex couples in Georgia.
The last straw was when Delta's CEO at the time suggested that Georgia needed to do more and raise its taxes to help fund transportation initiatives.
Delta was doing OK financially at the time, so state lawmakers had zero hesitation pulling the plug on that tax break.
If Delta were to lose this tax break, how much money would it lose?
So Delta would only gain about $40 million in this tax break.
And to put that in context, Delta just shared $1.1 billion with employees in profit-sharing a few weeks ago.
So Delta wouldn't really miss that money.
